May 1, 2020

Dear Parents and Guardians:

As expected, the Governor made his announcement about extending the school closure. All school buildings will be required to remain closed for the rest of this school year. Online learning, child care and food deliveries will remain as they are now.

The Governor shared that the decision on the ability to hold Summer School (as we usually do, not for all students) will come at the end of May as things continue to evolve.

Now that the decision has been made, I am sure that there will be further discussion about the specific date that remote learning will end this school year. We did not observe spring break, nor were we permitted to take off unused emergency closing days. I am sure that many districts will be raising these questions, and decisions to that end will be forthcoming.

In future sessions we look for information from the Governor regarding the budget vote and elections. Remember the school buildings are closed, not school. Our students are being educated each and every day.

Be Well,

Dr. Martin D. Handler
Superintendent

April 30. 2020

Dear Parents and Guardians:

Writing to you with my weekly update. I have very little new information to share with you this week. The Governor repeated today that he will let us know tomorrow the status of reopening the schools. We are hopeful that he will also answer other questions as well such as whether or not there can be summer school for those who need it, when and how we will hold the school budget vote, as well as some other questions that remain unanswered.

The one bit of news today involved the August administration of the Regents examinations. The State Education Department today cancelled that testing. This makes sense as August exams are generally re-takes for June failures. To remind you, students who successfully pass their Regents course this year will get credit for that Regents exam.

Please plan on another message from me tomorrow as soon as the Governor announces the information regarding the rest of the school year and potential for return.

Be well,

Dr. Martin D. Handler
Superintendent

If you have any questions please call your school office or the district office on Monday morning.

Dr. Martin Handler
Superintendent

Perhaps the most successful of these comes in the area of Food Services (cafeteria program) where Pine Plains, Rhinebeck, and Red Hook have teamed up to create cost efficiencies. The program of all three districts is under the excellent leadership of Mr. Larry Anthony, who has brought “economy of scale” to the program and innovative thinking to make the program cost effective while creating a more attractive and healthy menu. “Farm to school” programs have been established and efforts to reduce plastics and environmental impact are ongoing. This program is a “success story” and will encourage more inter-District cooperative ventures to contain costs.
